text: Thundering north through the glass canyons of the Loop, t elevated train SCREECHES through the city awakening. As i races north across the river past ancient factories givin way to high rise splendor, lights glistening against the  dawn, we see the complex business of bringing a city to l in the morning. On the Near North Side an assortment of revelers are wind up their night on the town. The pressmen loiter outside the Tribune loading docks, an fishing boats are outbound through the Chicago River lock A streetsweeping crew moves through the Fulton Market,  Chicago's central meat and produce distribution center. At the Merchandise Mart platform the elevated train picks two old cleaning ladies wearing babushkas.

The el train RUMBLES north past the aging tenements of Up into the Belmont Avenue Station. And down below, a garbage truck is slowly working its way the alley. A garbage man in city overalls WHISTLES to the driver and the truck stops. He rolls a can to the grindin jaw as the driver sits, tense and alert, scanning the str There's something odd about this driver. And the garbage too, for that matter.

SPIDER, a nervous looking black man, steps out onto the  platform. As the train pulls away we see him reach into h shirt pocket and CLICKS his ball point pen a couple of ti He WHISPERS into it. It is a concealed radio transmitter.
Say, hey, Cub fans, I hope to hell  y'all down there cause we got a big  game today.
He heads for the stairs and the street below.
The truck cab is equipped with a police radio. The driver RICH DONATO, adjusts the volume. Over the SPEAKER, HEAVY  WITH STATIC, we can hear the SOUND of the RECEDING EL TRA
(from radio) The school bus be waitin.
Donato motions for the garbage man.

EDDIE CUSACK jumps up on the truck's running board and st his head in. On the seat beside Donato is a sledgehammer a sawed off automatic rifle. The two men stare at each ot as they concentrate on the CRACKLING RADIO.
(from radio) S'happenin, Doc?
(from radio) Hey, I got it all right here, my  man. Jus be waitin on you.
(from radio) We ain't got far to go.
DOC is at the wheel of a late model Cadillac. Spider gets and they pull slowly away from the curb.

At the corner in a beat up Pontiac are officers MUSIC and BRENNAN. The two rough looking detectives follow Doc's ca through half closed eyes. They also HEAR Spider's TRANSMITTER. The quality of the  reception improves as Spider and his antennae clear the s support structure of the el platform.
(from radio) This early bird shit just ain't my  style.
(from radio) Dig it. Too close to real work for  me.
Doc and Spider talk in a nervous false bravado.
Eddie nods to Donato who grabs a walkie-talkie from the s
(to walkie-talkie) O.K. Home Team. Ready in the bullpen.
(from radio) Copy Shortstop. Double play. We're  with him now.
(from radio) Center's in.
SILENCE. Eddie looks at Donato.
Where's Cragie?

Two cops are against the wall separating the cemetery fro the El. CRAGIE, a weathered twenty-five year veteran; and NICK KOSALAS, the new kid on the team. Cragie sits on a c with a styrofoam cup of coffee. Kosalas is trying to maneuver his cup lid off, and still  hold on to his walkie-talkie.
(from radio) Talk to me left field.
(to mike) Ready sir. Left Field in position.
Cragie pulls a pint of whiskey from his pocket and sweete his coffee with a healthy shot. He notices Kosalas, who h set down the thermos and is nervously moving from leg to  leg.
Have a shot, kid. A little nerve  tonic.
What's the matter with you?
Cragie grins and raises his cup to drink. His hand shakes and he has to steady it with the other. The RADIO CRACKLES.
(from radio) O.K., guys, runner on first base.
A spotter, KOBAS, covers the scene from an abandoned buil across the street.
(to walkie-talkie) Just turning on Paulina.
(from radio) Double Play, you got him in sight?
(from radio) Yeah, we got the on him. He's headin  for the alley.

Eddie wrestles another garbage can into the truck's hoppe as Doc's car cruises slowly past. Eddie and Spider LOCK EYES for a split second. The car moves on and stops at the far end of the alley. T lights switch off. After a moment, Spider and Doc leave t car and check out the scene. Doc carries a satchel.
(from radio) I say nice and simple now.
(from radio) We real cool, Doc. We're frosty. We  jus' doin' a little business, you  know? Ain't no big thing.

The two men slip into the back gate of an old tenement. T pass through a gangway to the front of the building, and  climb the front stairs. Though we can no longer see them, we HEAR a DOOR OPENING, GREETING in Spanish, and FEET FOUNDING up the steps. The garbage truck GRINDS forward and halts again. Eddie c up to the cab. He is wearing a gun under his overalls. He and Donato listen on the RADIO to the CONVERSATION coming from inside the building.

A muscular Latino, POMPAS COMACHO, leads Spider and Doc d the paint-peeling corridor. The SOUND of BABIES CRYING an FAMILIES WAKING gives a sense of teeming humanity behind  every door. The Latino knocks at a door heavily fortified with burgla bars. The door opens. The bars are unlocked.
How y'all doin?
(from within) It's O.K. O.K. Como esta?
Pompas leaves the two men and heads down the stairs towar the front door.
Doc and Spider enter. They're patted down. A sleepy eyed Latino woman comes to stand in the bedroom  doorway. VICTOR COMACHO barks at her in Spanish, and she  disappears into the bedroom.
Eddie stands on the running board of the truck with Donat at the wheel. They listen to the RADIO.
(from radio) Hey, man, we're clean, huh. We ain't  fools.
You do that real nice, Pancho. what  say we get married.
Eddie tosses a soiled Rubic's Cube into Donato's lap.
Found you a present.
Shit, those things will fuck up your  mind.
Cragie is watching over the wall with his binoculars. He  looks back at Kosalas, who is hopping from foot to foot.
If you gotta take a leak, do it now.
I can't go wading in with my shlong  flapping in the wind.
Sure you can. It's called diversionary  tactics.
Cragie laughs and swigs straight from the bottle. The RAD CRACKLES.
(from radio) What's going on in the ballpark?
(from radio) Don't get froggy. Wait for the green  light.
A painter's van passes Brennan's Pontiac and parks in fro of the building half way up the block.
Music doesn't like this.
What the hell is this cat up to?
Going to work asshole. What do you  think.
At this hour.
They got a hardass for a boss. Like  us.
As Music and Brennan watch from their car, the four paint get out of their truck, unpack their ladders and tools, a begin to carry their equipment into the building next doo to the stakeout.

The room is small and bare. A selling den. VICTOR COMACHO and TWO COUSINS, all young and vicious, are sitting aroun formica table with the two buyers, Doc and Spider. The  Comachos are heavily armed. There is plenty of tension al around, but Doc seems a little more nervous than the rest This is an enormous buy. Doc has placed a bowling satchel full of bundled $20's, $50's, and $100's on the table. Vi is counting it rapidly.
This be better than jukin' Seven- Elevens, huh Victor?
(to cousins in Spanish) This one's got some balls, huh? (to Spider) I don't juke anybody.

Victor nods and one of the cousins brings in half a dozen brick-sized bundles of cocaine from the next room. Doc slices into one of the bags and with the tip of his k he drops a bit into a glass vial. He adds clear liquid wi an eye dropper and it instantly turns purple.
I say, awright. The royal colors.
Eddie's eyes scan the scene as he sorts through a garbage can with a stick.

The painters carry their equipment down the long corridor and enter a vacant apartment. A door opens in the corridor, and a naked toddler steps o A Latino teenager comes out to retrieve the child. He see the backs of the painters, and carries the toddler back  inside.

The painters are not what they seem. Working quickly,  silently, they open their tool kits and lay out their  hardware: machine guns and automatics. TONY LUNA, a barrel-chested Italian mobster is running th show and it's well rehearsed. His boys, GUS, VITO, and EE move like oiled machinery. Vito turns on a radio to a Latino station to cover the SO of their preparations. They remove the whole window from frame. Then they rest a wide plank on the window ledge. Three feet away is the window of the adjacent building an silhouetted against the shade we can SEE the drug deal. Luna'ys check their weapons. They put on painters' masks and goggles.
Okay, by the numbers.
He puts on his goggles.
Over the IDLING ENGINE of the garbage truck, Eddie and Do HEAR the deal going down on the RADIO.
(to walkie-talkie) Everybody on your toes.
(from radio) Their Right Field's Clear. Those  painters are out of the way.
(to walkie-talkie) What the hell you talking about?
(from radio) We got a painting crew of painters  just went in the building next door.
Eddie looks at Donato.
Painters? That building's gonna be  condemned!
Like a coiled spring, Eddie leaps from the truck and runs for the rear gate, gun in hand.
(shouts) Play Ball! Play-fucking-ball!
(to mike) Home Team! We're goin in! Move it!  Move it!

Tony and his men face the window across the gangway. Two them hold sawed off double barreled shotguns. Tony counts down, and they all fire as one. One GIANT BLAST tears into the window. It disintegrates. The four men toss aside their empty guns, and grab other  guns.
Eddie HEARS THE GUNFIRE and hits the wall. He sees the gl showering down around him. He vaults over the backyard fe and head for the porch stairs.
Kosalas is finally pissing against the wall.
I knew it.

Cragie is using the crate to climb the wall. He is up and over, and falls to the ground on the other side. He's sti trying to get to his feet when Kosalas comes over. They start running, yanking their guns out.

Doc and Spider are blown backwards in their chairs. One o the cousins has fallen across the piles of money and drug Victor and the other cousin are slumped on the floor. The woman in the bedroom is screaming. Through the jagged glass around the window frame, Tony's  boys shove a broad plank.
Three floors up, we see the "painters" rush across the ga to the other building.

EFREN COMACHO, the heavyweight guarding the back door, is distracted by the SHOUTS and GUNFIRE upstairs. Eddie cras through the door and Efren spins just in time to meet Edd blurring attack. The struggle on the landing is brief. Efren's size is no  match for Eddie's speed and power. With a grunt he sags t the floor. Eddie leaps over him and bounds up the steps.
Brennan, Music and Kobas are now on their way, using park cars to cover their advance toward the front door of the  Comacho building.

Eddie passes the second floor landing and takes a quick l up the porch stairs. The door to the second floor apartme starts to open behind him. He spins and kicks it. There stands a terrified old woman looking up the barrel his gun.
(shouts) Police! No se mueve!
He spins and bounds up the stairway.

The woman is huddled in a corner, still screaming. Tony c to stand over her, and coldly shoots her. Then he rips of his mask and goggles as his boys clear the bodies and sco up the drugs and money from the table. Victor Comacho lies slumped against the wall, one side of his face and one shoulder bloodied. He appears dead, eyes open. But then he blinks once.
Eddie has entered the rear of the apartment. He moves  cautiously forward.

Tony and his partners start back over the gangway to the  other building. Vito is bringing up the rear. Suddenly Victor Comacho comes to life. He gets off A BURS with his AUTOMATIC. Vito catches it in the back.
Donato is moving down the gangway when Vito's body -- fol by the scaffold plank -- falls from the sky and CRASHES i the pavement right in front of him.
Eddie jumps into the living room doorway, gun drawn, and  takes in the carnage. He kicks the gun out of Victor's ha and bounds to the shattered bay window and looks down in  time to SEE --
Donato jumps over the broken body, running through the ga toward the front of the building.
They're goin out the front!

The bridge to the other building is gone, but there is a  large drainpipe running down the outside of the building. Eddie climbs out on the shattered window sill, and stretc for the pipe. The pipe is just out of reach. Pushing off  from the ledge, he jumps for the drainpipe, grabbing it o his way down.
As he slides down three stories.
The painters run down the stairs toward the front of the  building.
Music, Brennan, and Kobas rush the front door of the Coma building, and enter.
Eddie lands on his feet and heads for the front.
Cragie and Kosalas brace themselves on each side of the r door to the Painters' building. Cragie is white with fear Kosalas kicks in the door. They enter.

At the front of the building Donato emerges from the  passageway and he's met by a HAIL of GUNFIRE. He jumps ba and takes a more cautious look. Tony Luna and Gus make a run for the van. Donato steps ou from between the two buildings and raises his gun. But he hasn't seen Eenie, just coming out of the building next door. Eenie fires and Donato goes down, wounded in the foot. Bu before Eenie can get off another shot -- -- Eddie leaps from the gangway and drops Eenie with a BU from his AUTOMATIC.

Luna pulls out PEELING RUBBER, but he's nearly surrounded squad cars have pulled in blocking both ends of the stree Another squad car screeches to a halt and both officers j out and start firing. Luna hits the fender of the squad car head on, knocking b officers to the ground. He spins the van around with cops FIRING from every angle, jumps the curb, and roars past t roadblock on the sidewalk with pedestrians leaping in all directions.
Heart pounding, Cragie leads Kosalas blindly up the darke steps.

A door opens behind Cragie. He whirls and FIRES into the  darkness. The riddled body of a Mexican teenager, eyes wide with sh pitches into the hall. Kosalas, down the hallway, hugs the wall, petrified.
Cragie?!
It's O.K. I got the sonovabitch.
Kosalas creeps ahead, gun drawn, just in time to see Crag pull a small handgun from his pocket and lay it in the bo hand. Cragie looks up at Kosalas and their eyes meet.
Luna's van, it's windshield shot out, takes the first cor on two wheels. Behind him the police scramble for their b and whites. Half way down the block, the van lurches into alley.

The van hurtles down the alley, splashing through puddles past the loading docks of a packing company. Parked along one side of the end of the alley is a meat truck from the opening montage. A loading ramp leads to the gaping rear  doors. The thieves have done their homework. The Luna gang slams the ramp into the rear of the meat truck. A bee fy compatriot in a blood stained butcher's smock pu several sides of beef along the rail and into the truck.  With the van concealed, the line of police cars ROAR spla by.
Cragie, kneeling over the body, looks at Kosalas eyeball eyeball. SCREAMS come from within the boy's apartment.
(yelling into the  apartment) Police! Stay where you are!

They HEAR FOOTSTEPS pounding up the front stairs. Cragie Kosalas look up. Eddie appears at the front of the hall, gun drawn. He see the boy on the hallway floor. He approaches cautiously, taking in the body, the gun, Cr sitting against the wall, and the distraught Kosalas who  stands transfixed by the dead kid. Eddie goes to Kosalas.
Take it easy, Kosalas.
The kid didn't dust him. I did.
Eddie looks at Cragie.
Him or me, Sarge. (pause) The kid saw the whole thing.
Both Eddie and Cragie look at Kosalas.
Tell him, Nick.
It almost sounds like an order. Kosalas looks like he's going to be sick.
(softly) Yeah, that's how it went down.
(pause) Stay here. (to Cragie) Take care of your partner.
Eddie walks away.

The gangway is now filled with squad cars, ambulances, an cops. As the paramedics walk Victor Comacho to the ambulance,  bloody, bandaged, but very much alive, he and Eddie LOCK  EYES for a brief instant. Several ferocious looking Comacho relatives have been all inside the police lines. One of them steps close to Victo
(to relative) Call Luis.
The lab technicians arrive. The throng of streetwise punks and horrified commuters ar across a roped off area.
Get these people back out of here,  wouldja.
Kosalas and Cragie are still with the body. The corridor blocked off by uniformed patrolmen. Kosalas is shakey. Cragie is tries to calm him down.
Look, it's no big thing, Kid. A  friggin' dog and pony show. Some  dumb ass questions by dumb ass  bureaucrats. "When's the last time  you were at the range?" Crap like  that.
Look. It was a fuckin' accident. Why  can't you just be --
(stiffens) You born yesterday?! These ain't  cops. They'll roast our ass just  cause we carry a badge. Both of us. (menacing) We stick together on this, kid. We're  partners, right?
Kosalas nods.
Donato sits on the ground as two paramedics work on his f Eddie crouches beside him as one medic cuts away Donato's ankle boot.
Aw man, don't do that. You know how  much these things cost?
He gasps as they draw the boot off. Donato grabs for Eddi hand, and squeezes against the pain.
Eddie. Scam this. A bait shop. Worms,  minnows. Don't even need real worms.  Storage problem. Got those rubber  ones, you know?
Yeah, what about the winter?
We winter in Florida. Rubber neck  the beach bunnies. Aw, look at that.  Ruined my brand new fence climbers.  Hand made in Italy.
Someone points Eddie out to Partida, an attractive, no- nonsense woman, who heads for him. Donato sees Partida co
Oh, fuck, Partida. I'm gonna tell  her you shot me.
The resentment the other cops feel against Partida is rea apparent.
Cusack. You were in charge here?
Does it look like it?
Partida looks at the covered body nearby.
(to Donato) And you were a principal in one of  the shootings?
Eddie nods.
OW! A goddamn Dr. Jekyll!
Eddie smiles at Donato, who with his good foot, kicks at medic bandaging the wound.
Where's the officer who was involved  in the other shooting?
(pointing) Third floor rear.

As Partida heads for the building, another suited civilia comes over to meet her. The civilian escorts a Mexican  grandmother. The old lady is agitated, jabbering in Spanish and pointi at the cops. Eddie sees this, and then is pulled away as he helps one the medics lift Donato and carry him to the ambulance. Eddie helps Donato into the ambulance.
Catch you later, Hopalong.

The two Comacho lookouts who survived the raid, Efren and Pompas, have been brought in for questioning. The  interrogation is taking place in a small room. Officers Brennan and Music are here with Eddie. The Comachos sit silent as stones.
(to Efren) You know that, Efren. When your big  bad brother Luis gets the word, your  ass is freeze dried and fried.
Efren stares ahead. Music looks at Eddie who is fiddling  with the Rubic's Cube, to little success. Brennan takes Music's place. He kicks Pompas' chair hard.
Talk you hemorrhoid!
(in Spanish) Your mother fucks dogs in the street.
You wanna tune-up? Hey Sarge, you  know why a Comacho's like a cue-ball?  Cause the harder you hit 'em, the  better their English gets.
It's not a joke, but a threat. Pompas spits at Brennan.  Brennan is enraged, but Eddie pushes him back with a hand Eddie faces the Comachos.
We're jerking off here.
Eddie goes out the door.
As Eddie emerges, he bumps into the Camacho's lawyer SANC thirty-eight, well dressed, smooth as silk. Sanchez sees the tableau in the room. As Cusack walks dow the hall the attorney follows him.
Let's cut the shit, Cusack.
Eddie ignores him.

Option 1: you can send em downtown.  If Judge Collins didn't get laid  last night, you can probably get him  to arraign my clients for loitering  in their own hallway. He'll set bail.  I'll take care of it. Option 2:  release them here and now and we'll  call it a day. (pause) Up to you.
I like to see you earn your money.
Sanchez backs off. We follow Eddie down the hall.
The head of Area Four, COMMANDER KATES, is grilling Cragi and Kosalas.

We come up the back stairs. We start  cleanin' the hallway when the deceased  pops out of a doorway with a 25  automatic. I tell him to drop it,  but he's comin. We had no choice.  Kosalas here saw the whole thing.
Kates turns to Kosalas.
Did you?
Kosalas looks haggard.
I was on another doorway...
But you saw the action?
I saw him fall.
And the kid was armed?
That's the way it went down.
And you saw the weapon?
(nods) Yes sir. I saw it in his hand.
O.K. (signs document) Cragie, you'll be assigned to  headquarters until the hearing --
Hearing? Who called for a hearing?  The little fuck tried to shoot me in  the back!
Eddie enters. Kates looks up from his desk.
Ms. Partida --
That piece of shit!

Shut-up, Cragie. (pause) Partida has demanded a formal hearing.  You will be under oath so the  department will provide you with a  lawyer unless you've got your own. (stands) An OPS Review Board member is waiting  to talk to you. Doesn't sound like  you got anything to worry about.
Cragie gets up. Kosalas, sitting through this interview i stunned silence stands also.
Kosalas, you work with Cusack until  this is over.
Yes sir.
Kosalas and Cragie exit.
I ain't got no time to nursmaid a  rookie. I don't need a partner.

(explodes) Your right! You don't need a partner!  You need a goddamn keeper! (slams fist on desk) Jesus Christ! How do I explain this  one upstairs? (stands) We gave you 600 man-hours, you took  a month planning the damn thing, and  what have you got to show for it?  Nine bodies? A dead informant? One  of my best men shot! For Christ's  sake! (stares at ceiling) You're going to have me back on a  beat busting perverts in the park.
Kates sits, sighs, suddenly tired.
We got a bigger problem. These  Comachos aren't gonna take this lying  down. The animals are out of the  cages.
Just what I need. A goddman war.
Eddie turns to leave.
Keep track of this business with  Cragie?
Yeah.
The PHONE RINGS.
I'll deal with upstairs.
Eddie starts to leave again. Kates picks up the phone, an puts a hand over the mouthpiece.
Just get me some answers, huh.
That's my job.
Eddie exits.
Kosalas, without an attorney, is being interviewed by Par A court stenographer is silently typing.
...you have the right to remain  silent. You have the right to have  an attorney present at all times.  Anything you say may be used against  you in a court of law...

Eddie and Kosalas are parked on an airport access road,  watching private planes land and take off. Eddie's car, a five-year old Chevy, is wreckage. The quarter panels are  rusted, the radio antenna is a coathanger, and when Kosal pushes a tape into the cassette player, the windshield wi start moving. Kosalas pops the cassette out, the windshield wipers stop he throws the cassette into the glove compartment. But no he can't get the door to stay closed.
I'm going to have to fix that.
Eddie has to shout to be heard over the sound of an airpl passing directly overhead. Eddie glances at Kosalas who looks uncomfortable.
You know, it's kind of interesting.  That 16 year old in the hallway with  the gun? Partida told me he doesn't  have a record. The kid's never been  arrested.
Yeah, well, you know, if you read  the papers, cops only shoot honor  students. Sole support of the family  and all that.
The airport bristles with corporate jets departing and  arriving.
...Lear 9 Lima Kilo number 2 for  landing -- wind south 20, altimeter  two-niner-niner-two...

And now comes a mystery jet, wearing no company colors,  banking in over Lake Point Tower and WHISTLING low over t Planetarium to a touchdown. The white Learjet taxis to a halt at the far end of the f as an undistinguished Buick rolls down the ramp to meet i Eddie and Kosalas stand by their car, parked across the r from the Learjet. The jet's engines shut down, the door opens, and a grim b handsome man emerges. LUIS COMACHO, a cruel and uncomprom survivor, has arrived. With him is an incredibly beautifu exotic woman. He is met by Pompas and Efren Comacho, the two lookouts w survived the raid. And Victor Comacho, who was wounded in the raid, is here with his shoulder bandaged.

From where Eddie and Kosalas are standing it is impossibl to hear the conversation at the Learjet, but it is clear  that Luis Comacho is upset. They see Luis slap Pompas and Efren. Then he grabs Victor by both arms, ignoring his wo and screams at him.
Nice fellow this Luis Comacho. Donato  says they call him the Angel-of-Death.
Victor grimaces, in great pain, and his knees buckle.
Real sweetheart.
In the dining room DIANA LUNA, a pretty 19 year old, help her 80 year old grandmother THERESA decorate a "HAPPY  BIRTHDAY" banner, some red and green crepe paper.
Now?
No!
Diana and her grandmother grin at each other. They are do Theresa stands back to admire their work.
Now?
Mama!
Daddy, would you get that!
Diana rushes into the kitchen and comes right out with a  birthday cake, and sets it on the table next to some pres
Bella.
Diana goes to the stairs where her mother sits with her h over her eyes.
Keep 'em closed now.
She leads her mother to the dining room.
O.K., open 'em.
MOLLY LUNA opens her eyes. Theresa and Diana beam. Diana  kisses her mother who almost cries.
Happy birthday, momma.
(in Italian) Happy birthday, Molly.
Diana hands Molly a card from the table. Molly starts to  open it. Tony Luna burst in from another room.
Molly! Pack me a bag! Quick! Ok?  C'mon I'm in a hurry!
Molly heads for the stairs, leaving behind the half opene card.
But Tony, why...?
Business! C'mon, move. Do what I  tell you!
Molly goes upstairs. Diana is pissed.
Don't do it, momma! Make him pack  his own bag.
I ain't got time to put up with your  bullshit today.
Tony goes to the phone, dials, gets a busy signal, and sl it down. Theresa sits down watching sadly. Diana goes to stand in front of her father.
Listen goddammit! It's momma's  birthday! She deserves better'n this!
Tony sorts through the closet looking for a jacket. Gamiani comes in puffing with a clumsily wrapped present  under his arm.
Hey, Tony. What's shaking? Sorry I'm  late. I got stuck on Wacker. Some  spook...
Victor Comacho is alive.
Oh sweet Jesus.
Diana is really angry at her father ignoring her.
You can't go now.
Shut up!
He slaps her. She slaps him back, turns, grabs her purse, and runs out. Tony watches her go and turns to Gamiani.
Put someone on the house. And you  keep an eye on her.
He nods out the door.
You got it, Tony. What about your  uncle?
What Felix don't know doesn't hurt  him.
Molly comes down with the bag. Tony takes it from her and starts out the door. Suddenly he turns back, snatches  Gamiani's present from his hands, and thrust it at his wi
Here. Happy birthday.
Tony rushes out the door. Gamiani goes to the phone. Molly is left alone in the doorway.
Eddie parks in front of his apartment building, leaves th car, and enters the building.
Dead on his feet, Eddie reaches the top of the stairs and object comes flying at him out of the shadows. ODELL, a s 10 year old black kid, fakes a series of karate kicks at  Eddie.
Bow to your master!
Later, Odell. It's been a rough one.
Y' tellin me! We all seen it on the  TV!
Odell!
Bow to your master.
Odell takes off.
Hey, Odell. Here, make yourself crazy.
The kid stops, and Eddie tosses him the Rubic's Cube. Eddie nears his apartment, we hear a MALE VOICE SINGING.
The door is ajar. Eddie lives in a modest apartment. FRED PIRELLI, a great bear of a man, 65, sings at the top of h lungs. He is bent over the space heater, tearing it apart
You look like shit.
Thanks, pal.
They had a shot on the tube of you  guys comin' out in front of the  building. How's Donato?
Eddie collapses on the sofa.
Pissed cause he lost a shoe. (pause) Luis Comacho is in town.

He'll collect himself some scalps  before this one's over. Your answering  machine is on the fritz again. Some  woman with a fantastic voice was  callin' about comin' over this weekend  ta help you with somthin', and then  the tape went nuts.
Want somthin' to drink?
Does the Pope shit in the woods? Is  a bear Catholic?
Me too.
Odell shows in the doorway. Eddie gets up and the kid tos him the Rubic's Cube -- all done. Eddie looks at it, and the kid goes into the kitchen.
I hate smart ass kids.
Odell laughs.
Gonna get down in the 30's tonight.  Your pilot light is out.
Eddie tosses the Cube into the waste basket and opens the refrigerator.
I've been told that more than once.
(seriously) So, who you figure pulled out the  rug? Gypsies? Mob?
Eddie comes back into the living room, hands a beer and a soda to Odell, and flops back on the sofa with his own be
Somebody knew what they were doin'.  They blew the top off an anthill.
Pirelli reaches for his drink and Odell hands him the sod Pirelli grabs the beer before Odell can drink and switche
I'd figure the Mob but Scalese ain't  that stupid. (pause) Hah! Sombody put the valve in  backwards.
Pirelli and Odell turn to Eddie who tries to look innocen but fails. Eddie purposefully studies the answering machi on the coffee table in front of him.
Odell! I ain't calling you again!
Later, fellas.
Pirelli finishes with the heater, and gets up.
There. Heat.
What was the Cubs final score?
8 to 1.
Eddie punches a button on the answering machine. It spews tape across the table.
Machines just don't like you.
Pirelli grabs the machine, unplugs it, and carries it out the door toward his own apartment.
Maybe I don't like machines.

The machine in question looks like a miniature tank. This the "Prowler," a robot anti-terrorist vehicle that is bei maneuvered around various obstacles in a demonstration fo the city's law enforcement agencies. The "Prowler" is amazingly agile. And its BULLHORN VOICE  breaks everybody up.
(from speaker) Arretez! Halten Zie! Stop! Do not  move! No se mueve!...

The machine's three video eyes, searching the crowd  independently, give it the appearance of an extra-industr bug. One camera is mounted on a telescoping mast which ex to give it the perspective of a giraffe. The thing seems  almost alive. Commander Kates is here, leading a contingent of departme brass. With them are several dozen officers and a gaggle city councilmen. The Prowler is being put through its paces by the FACTORY ENGINEER. He controls the machine with a pistol-grip devi that looks like a small TV camera.
...After the gyros are locked, any  movement of the hand controller is  duplicated by the 'Prowler.'
He turns his hand to the right and the Prowler, 50 yards  away, sweeps its turret to the right, aiming the twin 30  calibre machineguns at the politicians. They move aside.
This simple control system means  that even semi-skilled employees can  operate the unit with a minimum of  training. As they say, "Even a child  can operate it."
Standing with Chief Kates, Eddie watches the demonstratio with contempt. Kates turns to him.
He's talking about you, Cusack. Pay  attention. You're all gonna have to  be qualified on this. It's the future.
Just what the world needs, another  gun without a brain.
You're looking at the perfect cop.  The damn thing follows orders.
Eddie has seen enough.
I got better things to do than play  with toys.
Kates is about to say something when the demonstrator  interrupts.
If the Commander will pick someone  to try and elude 'Prowler,' we can  show how our various target  acquisition systems function.

Kates points to Eddie, and smiles. Instantly the turret sweeps the horizon and locks on Eddi as he walks across the astro turf. CLOSE-UP of the Prowler's hand controller. The MONITOR SCREEN shows the crosshairs on the back of Ed head. ON THE SCREEN the digital readout says: LOCKED AND  TRACKING.
(from speaker) Bang. You're dead.
Eddie keeps walking, seemingly oblivious to the Prowler.  Suddenly he whirls and ducks behind a wall out of the  Prowler's sight. He pops up with his gun pointed at the Prowler's controll
Drop it.
The controller, scared shitless, drops the hand control. The Prowler dies -- the plug pulled. Eddie smiles at Kates, and exits.

The curtain is drawn back from the viewing window and the Comachos SEE the bodies of their cousins. Luis is here wi Pompas, Efren, and Victor. Their attorney, Sanchez, has j them. They are speaking Spanish.
(subtitle) A war does no good for any of us. It  can only make what is bad worse.
Luis says nothing. He looks through the window at the bod Finally he speaks.
(subtitle) Get them out of here. Fix them up. I  want them to be beautiful for their  mother.
He kisses his fingertips and touches the glass.
(subtitle) I promise you, my brothers, there  will be blood for blood.
Sanchez sighs.
Luis Comacho storms out of the room into the corridor fol by the others. Eddie and Kosalas are just entering. Victor spots Eddie a turns to Luis.
(subtitles) This is the cop.
The Comachos slow down. The two groups survey each other Luis, hatred oozing from his eyes. And Eddie, without slo looks the vicious Colombian over with cool contempt. Eddie walks by.
How much did they pay you to set up  my brothers, Pig.
Eddie freezes, makes a slow turn, and meets Luis' eyes. Suddenly Eddie moves, faster than anyone else can react t and he has Luis pinned to the wall, choking him.
Stay off my streets, asshole. Or  I'll bite your head off, and shit in  your neck.
He releases Luis just as quickly, and turns to walk out,  Kosalas backing with him, hand on gun. Luis gets some air back, and starts to scream.
(subtitle) You're meat cop! Dead meat!
The other Comachos have to restrain him.

Retired detective HANK FLANNIGAN runs the high-tech morgu where the bodies are stacked on trays like bakery buns.  Flannigan, a trim, bespectacled Mr. Clean, clicks his fal teeth between thoughts. The body on the exotic lab table is the gunman Eddie shot during the raid. Eddie is here to confirm the identificat His new partner, Kosalas, is with him, very uncomfortable this setting.
Eenie Verona is the gentleman's name. (looks down) You did a hell of a job on him.
I was motivated.
Flannigan has already pulled Verona's record. He hands it Eddie who passes it on to Kosalas without looking at it.  Kosalas concentrates on the file, uneasy with the dead.
Know him?
He's a punk. Punk thief. Booster.
Looks like he graduated.
He had a brother-in-law. They were  tight. Served time together.  Ganelli..., Gagleone...
Gamiani.
Eddie looks at Kosalas who glances up from the report  triumphantly.
If I was you, I'd sit on him.
You figure he's connected?
Eddie just smiles.
Looks like you're gonna be busy,  Cusack. Uh, you gonna be using those  Cubs' tickets?
Eddie reaches into his pocket, and tosses a ticket to  Flannigan who grins.
Eddie and Kosalas cruise the Rush Street area at night. T search the neon lit crowds on the sidewalks for a glimpse Lou Gamiani.
On a tree-shaded block of classic brownstones, the unmark car is parked at the corner.
Eddie is at the wheel wearing a sportscoat and sweater,  scanning the sports page. Kosalas is nervous and chatty,  bubbling. He's still reading the records from the morgue.
This Ganiani's a swinger, huh?
He's just makin' up for the time he  spent in the joint.

LOU GAMIANI, 55, Italian, and huge, comes out the front d of a brownstone, and gives a perfunctory kiss to his agin "Playmate", who stands in the doorway in a housecoat. Gam comes down the steps, and jumps into a car. In the car with Gamiani, a fat man, TITO, is at the wheel They pull into the street passing the unmarked car.
Trailing Gamiani and his partner through the North Side  neighborhoods, they wind up in Lincoln Park. With considerable skill Kosalas and Eddie manage to stick them undetected.
Gamiani and Tito park by the botanical gardens and stroll past the fields of flowers into the zoo. Eddie and Kosala follow.
Now what? They selling protection to  the bears?
Relax kid.

Strolling among the baby elephants and fuzzy rabbits, the two heavies could not be more out of place. Tito has a ra form. Lou, tall enough to see over heads, looks like a lo gorilla on the prowl. He is searching for somebody. Surrounding the incubators filled with hatching chicks is cluster of schoolchildren. They are having a ball. Eddie has noticed DIANA, a lovely 19 year old who is in c of the children. And she has noticed Gamiani. She's visibly upset.
What's this? Kinda young for that  old fart ain't she?
Just watch, kid. Learn.
Diana leaves the children with the zoo lecturer.
Be back in a minute.
She crosses to the two goons and looks up at Gamiani.
What do you want?
Your Papa worries about you.
Get out of here, Lou. Leave me alone.
Gamiani shrugs, his pal Tito seems embarrassed, but they  don't move.

The CHILDREN SCREAM, and LULU, the half-ton baboon flies  into frame, swinging down from the artificial branches of iron tree in the three story central cage. The children c at Diana in delightful terror. The gorilla, inches away,  kisses the thick glass that separates them. Lulu swings to the upper branches and sits, arms crossed, staring eyeball-to-eyeball at her human counterpart, Gami Tito eats popcorn. Eddie and Kosalas walk behind a mother and child, each ho a balloon.

Diana is on the front steps of the library saying good-by to two of the children from the zoo. She hands them over their mothers, and goes up the steps into the building. Gamiani and Tito pull over and park down the street. Eddie comes around the corner, and follows her in.
The sign on the door tells us this is the city's Special  Education Program office. Diana enters the office and con briefly with another staff member.
Through the open door of the Special Education Program of Eddie observes Diana chatting with her co-workers.
Eddie follows as Diana walks through the great hall past  long tables and out the other door.

Diana comes down the steps, wading through the swarm of  homebound commuters, and catches a cab. And head and shoulders above the crowd, scanning the tops heads, is Lou Gamiani. Tito comes around the corner in his car, and pulls up to curb. Gamiani jumps in, and they take off after Diana's c Eddie and Kosalas follow in Eddie's car.
Diana enters an apartment building.
By the time Diana exits it is dark. She is with a friend, and both are in some kind of Halloween costume. They catc cab.

The taxi stops in front of an ancient brick loft building Diana and her friend get out and hit the buzzer at an unm door. The door opens and they disappears inside. Gamiani's car cruises past. It pulls up at the corner and it's lights switch off. Eddie's car pulls up. Eddie hops out. Kosalas slides behi the wheel.
Eddie leans down to the open drivers window.
Hold here a second.

Eddie goes to the back of the car, and Kosalas follows hi in the rearview mirror, losing sight when Eddie pops open the trunk. Kosalas watches the party goers enter the building. There is a tapping at the window. Eddie has donned a baseball uniform, matching cap, and no carries a baseball bat with a pair of cleats hanging from it.
Keep with Gamiani.
Eddie tosses the keys back to Kosalas, and heads to the  building. Kosalas calls to him.
Bang a few for me.
In the darkened stairway Eddie joins a group of outrageou dressed characters. The door at the top of the stairs bur open on a punk-funk art student Halloween party.

A hundred people are jammed into the studio. It feels lik the Star Wars Saloon. The LIVE MUSICIANS match the look o the party. The costumes are outrageous. Everyone is danci Eddie looks the place over. He spots Diana. Eddie walks over to her, grabbing a drink along the way. sidles up to Diana.
Wanna play ball?
She looks him over taking in the outfit, the bat.
Are you pitching?
Some people say I've got a pretty  good inside curve.
I don't know. You look strictly minor  league.
She smiles.
I'm Eddie.
I make it Eddie-The-Cop.
You've had a lot of experience with  cops?
All bad.

She is angry now, and walks away from him. Eddie watches her go, and is about to follow. He sets his drink down, and turns to find a girl, luscious as hell,  dressed like a Frederick's wet dream, making eyes at him. She takes his bat, and gives it a long, lascivious lick.
You'll get slivers.
He walks by her.
Eddie steps over and around an assortment of wasted witch and gooned out goblins snorting lines on the coffee table get to Diana who is tensely by herself. He grabs her purse.
Hey, what the hell do you think you're  doing?
I thought you knew all about cops.  You don't put anything up your nose  do you?
Eddie searches Diana's purse. He find her drivers license
Diana Luna? (pause) You're Tony Luna's daughter?
He drops the license into the purse and hands it back to  her. She stares him in the eye defiantly.
I don't know where he is, and I don't  really give a shit. (tired) When are you people going to realize  I don't have anything to do with my  father.
Eddie tries to give her his card.
For when you need a friend.
She won't take it.
I've got all the friends I want.
Eddie puts the card into her purse.
But do you have all the friends you  need?
She walks away angrily. Eddie watches her leave, and then steps over a few of the wasted witches to get to the phon on the drug laden coffee table. He dials.

(to phone) This is Sergeant Cusack. I want a  team to cover a house on the southwest  side. (pause) L-U-N-A, Anthony. (pause) Yeah. Crazy Tony Luna. I don't think  he's around, but if he shows up bring  him in.
The dope-smoking party-goers stare at this cop in shock. of the ladies tries to casually cover the cocaine with a  magazine. Eddie hangs up the phone, and pushes past them the door.
(nods) Catch you later.
He is out the door.
Several plainclothes officers, some of them women, stand either side of the door with their backs to the wall, gun at the ready. One of the men reaches out and POUNDS on th door.
Police! Open up!
They rush the door and SMASH it, SHOUTING and scrambling  into the apartment.
(from bullhorn) Awright awright hold it.
The instructor, Kobas, walks in criticizing their style.
For Christ's sake! You tryin to get  your partner killed, Jackson?
This is not the real thing; only practice.

The apartment is only a mockup set in the corner of this  vast skylit city warehouse. Runners race around the track the perimeter. On the wall are large photos and diagrams of the Prowler. Below the photos are sign-up sheets for the required trai sessions. In another corner is the weight room, the ring, and the  workout area. Eddie is here, working out, sparring with a partner who has large padded mits on each hand.

Brennan and a couple of buddies approach Kosalas as he ti his gym shoes. Brennan is carrying a petition. He hands i to Kosalas and looks around the room. He spots another co Cragie is in the background putting on his jacket.
(shouts across the  room) Hey, Mahoney. I want you to help me  get some signatures on this letter  for Cragie.
Brennan looks down at Kosalas who is hesitating. Kosalas  looks back at Cragie. There eyes meet. He signs. Cragie comes by and slaps him on the back.
Way to go, partner.
We see Music talking to several cops working out the exer machines, and getting signatures on Cragie's petition.
Eddie gives his sparring partner, Howard, a furious serie of blows, driving him back. They are kickboxing.
Let's try the mitts for awhile.
Eddie nods. He sees Cragie cross the gym and exit. As Cra goes out, Donato comes in on crutches. Everybody shouts a greeting. Eddie sits down to change gloves, and take his footpads o
Say, partner.
How ya doing, Richie?
Swinging. How's this? Two G's, we  get a sausage and beef stand stand  outside Wrigley Field. You pass the  beef, I take the cash. Free games. I  got a contact downtown.
How you gonna watch the game if you're  hawking sandwiches?
Never thought of that. TV? Hey, I  tell you about this nurse I met?  Talk about physical therapy.
The sparring partner returns, and Eddie goes back to prac
She's got this friend just dying to  meet you. Intensive care.
Eddie grins. Brennan comes up to Donato, and hands him the petition. D signs quickly.
(to Eddie) Later, partner.
Eddie nods to him, concentrating on the sparring.
Hey, Cusack. How about taking the  gloves off long enough to sign this  for Cragie.
This about the hearing?
You bet.
I pass.
(angry) What the fuck's the matter with you?
He's burnt, Brennan, and you know  it. He was a good cop, but he ain't  now.
PUNCH! Eddie hits the mit so hard that Howard is knocked  back a couple of steps.

Get off your high horse, Cusack. He  made a couple of mistakes, OK. The  guy was a hero. What the fuck does a  bunch of civilians know about comin'  up some shithouse stairway day after  day, scared outta your shorts.
PUNCH! With a whirling kick, Eddie knocks the mit right o of the Howard's hand, and across the gym. Eddie turns to face Brennan, nose to nose.
We're all scared, Brennan. Cragie  should have been off the street a  long time ago. He's gonna hurt  somebody else with his bullshit.  Maybe even you.
Eddie goes back to punching. Brennan storms out.

A funeral cortege makes it's way sedately down the street past the Comacho owned pool hall. Two hearses, a flower c a limo, and several other cars with funeral stickers on t windshields pass bye. The slain Comacho cousins from the  raid are being escorted to the cemetery. Luis Comacho is in the limo along with the woman from the airport.
Brennan and Music are following the procession. Brennan i on the radio.
(to mike) The funeral director says they plan  on cruisin right past luna's house.

Tito, one of Tony Luna's bodyguards, watches from the ste of Luna's porch as a procession of cars follows the hears slowly up the street. At the end of the block, an old man is selling produce to the neighborhood housewives off the tailgate of his truck They watch the procession in wonder.
The cortege passes the unmarked car down the block from T house. Eddie is watching. Kosalas is with him.
(to radio) They're wastin' the show. Tony's not  even in town.
He'll get the word.
Across the street, WE SEE another bodyguard joint Tito on the front steps. They stand, arms folded, watching the  procession.
Luis Comacho takes a flower and tosses it out the window he cruises past the two goons. Their EYES LOCK. Tito walk up and grinds the flower into the ground with his shoe.
Brennan and Music bring up the rear in their ummarked car
Tito, the body guard, picks up the phone.
At the pay phone next to a lakeside bait shop, Tony Luna getting the word. He's worried.
(to phone) What the fuck are you talkin about?  Nobody's gonna touch nothin. Just  stay put. (pause) I give a shit about their fuckin  parade?
A floozy slides up next to him, and he puts an arm around her waist.
(to phone) They wanna throw flowers we can fix  it so they're pushing up daisys.
He laughs. The girl joins in like she's supposed to.

A tan Dodge rolls over the rutted scrapyard roadway, boun toward the immense old warehouse along the river's edge. city seems to have abandoned this remote industrial area; giant grain elevators, rusting freighters and vast scrapy surround us.
Pompas and Efren Comacho drive through the gate and enter the warehouse as the door opens for them.

The car halts in the vast empty chamber. It is quickly  surrounded by members of the Comacho family. They begin t unload the car. The trunk is filled with cases of heavy  ammunition. At the back of the warehouse, other Comachos are test fir their weapons.
Luis is directing things as they are preparing for battle The weaponry spread on the table is astonishing.
Eddie's beat up Chevy is parked beyond the line of yachts toward the end of the pier. Eddie gets out of the car. Ko looks worried.
I can back you up.
Stay by the radio.
Eddie walks to the 75 foot steel cruiser tied to the end the pier. Eddie walks up the gangplank.
An ape in a suit, ROCCO, appears.
What the hell you doin' here? Off,  asshole.
Rocco goes for Eddie. A couple of quick blows and Rocco i in the water. Eddie continues up the gangway to the rear the boat.

Eddie finds FELIX (THE RAIL) SCALESE sitting on a chaise  lounge, reading. A beautiful girl lays on her stomach on deck pad typing at a personal computer terminal. Scalese looks up at Eddie. He is momentarily discombobula but recovers.

(referring to computer) The modern age's answer to the crystal  ball. Marvelous. If you know how to  read it. (pause) Listen. If you have some extra cash,  buy oranges. The price is low, and I  can promise you the threatened  trucking strike will be avoided.
We talking about a bribe, Scalese?
It's a prediction.
Another beautiful bikinied girl comes by and gives Scales tall cool drink.
No. I wouldn't try to bribe Eddie  Cusack.
He drops the name with a smile. Eddie doesn't react.
You're incorruptible. Untarnished. I  hear they call you stainless steel  on the street. Me, I think you're a  fuckin' pain in the ass.
Thanks.
(frowning) It's not a compliment.
I'm looking for your nephew.
Tony? Forget it. Tony Luna's none of  your business.
Wrong. Tony just made himself my  business.
No he didn't. We take care of our  own. Just like the cops. Just like  the Comachos. You understand.
Eddie sits down next to Scalese and looks him in the eye.
He shit on my turf, old man. And I'm  going to nail him and anybody else  tied to him. You understand, Felix?
(with cool rage) Nobody threatens Felix Scalese.
(softly) It's not a threat. It's a prediction.
On the shore, Kosalas is honking the car horn to get Eddi attention. Eddie rises.
There's a shitstorm coming. You better  get yourself a good umbrella.
The girl at the computer terminal watches him leave.
Eddie walks by as Rocco, soaking wet, is pulling himself  from the water. Eddie pushes him into the water again. Kosalas is still sounding the HORN.
Eddie runs toward the car.

A body lies in the flowers in the service area next to th giant greenhouse. Several unmarked cars and two blue and  whites are parked in the dirt drive as Eddie and Kosalas  pull up. The cops have roped off the area. Music and Bren are there. Eddie looks at the body as Music comes over.
Tony Luna's bagman.
Kosalas looks at the body.
They call that a Columbian necktie.
Kosalas winces.

They found the manager of Tony's  restaurant hanging from a hook in  his kitchen. Looked like someone  tried to carve a canoe out of him.  Tony's used car lot on Ashland is  burning as we speak. The head salesman  is a fried zuccini.
Oh Jesus. It's starting.
Eddie stands to one side.
Let's go.

A kid on a bike makes his way up the quiet tree-lined str tossing newspapers onto the porches of the block. Around the corner at the end of the block, the produce tr starts slowly forward. As it turns onto Luna's block, a c pulls up behind it and stops, blocking the street. The produce truck parks at the curb in front of the Luna  house. A neighbor from across the street approaches. The  front door of Luna's house opens, and Tito emerges, helpi Tony's aged mother down the steps to buy vegetables.
On the floor near the wheelwell is the dead produce man.

The rear doors of the produce truck swing open. The neigh Tito, and Tony's mother are instantly killed. From outside three Comachos enter the open front door of Luna house. We hear the SOUND of MUFFLED GUNFIRE from ins

Bits and pieces. A Shattered orange juice container. Eggs cooking on the stove. A woman's vanity. On the floor; a woman's legs, a housecoat, slippers. A  silhouette of a Comacho in the hallway RAKING one of Tony guards. A family photo on the mantle which includes Diana and her father is BLASTED to bits.
One of Tony's men tries to escape through the back of the house. He is pursued by a Comacho who guns him down.
Luis Comacho sits in a car in the next block surveying th scene. The cousins are walking briskly out. They jump in car and drive off.
Luis nods to his driver. They pull away.
The street is QUIET again. Next door, a neighbor, wearing only his underpants and carrying an old pistol, stands  trembling in disbelief.

Pines reflect in the dappled lake as Tony Luna rows slowl for shore. He ties up at the dock. He's taking his tackle out of the boat when one of his boys comes running down t the dock. We cannot hear the conversation but we can see Tony drop tackle box and we can hear his SCREAM echo across the wat
Eddie runs down the rear stairs to Kosalas' unmarked car. opens the driver's door, pushes Kosalas across the seat, gets behind the wheel. He PEELS OUT.
Music's at the scene.
Eddie picks up the mike.
(to mike) Was there a girl? Late teens. Reddish  hair.
(on radio) Two male caucasians, two female. One  mid-to-late forties. The other a  grandmother.
With the SIREN full out, LEANING ON the HORN, he simply p his foot on the floor and sends the car into a four wheel drift that slides into a neat U-turn.
Eddie leaves the car running, and burst through the main  entrance flashing his badge at the stunned security guard
Eddie races through the corridors and reading rooms searc Kosalas arriving at his heels.
Gamiani tells Diana about her mother and grandmother.
Three Comachos; Pompas, Efren, and ANGEL, search for Dian
Lou Gamiani emerges from the building with Diana. She is  terrified. He checks out the scene, then descends the crowded steps crosses the street, keeping a sharp lookout.
Luis and Victor Comacho loiter by the outdoor flower stan next to the library. They watch the activity on the libra steps.

Distracted for an instant by a cluster of conventioneers, Lou fails to notice the two Comachos who have fallen in s behind them. He goes down with a gasp, almost silently, a knife sticking from his back. A Comacho grabs Diana's arm She jabs him in the eyes, and runs. Diana disappears into the crowd. Hysterical citizens scatter in all directions. A woman st in horror unable to keep from looking at Gamiani's body l on the sidewalk. She SCREAMS. Eddie and Kosalas come crashing out of the entrance of th museum. The girl isn't here. Eddie spots a commotion at the end of the block, under th el station. He dashes down the steps and across the street with traff screeching to a halt. Kosalas flags down a blue and white, and barks for backup then tears out after Eddie.

In the shadow of the el tracks, Diana runs for her life,  racing north on Wabash through crowds of shoppers with th Comachos moving relentlessly a half block behind. Opposite Marshall Field's, she abruptly cuts across traff and runs into an alley between the giant men's and women' stores. With terror in her eyes, Diana runs, searching franticall for a guard, a policeman, somebody with a gun. But the  Comachos are closing in on her. She dives through a revolving door into the building.
Diana runs past the perfume displays, notions, and linger and out the Randolph Street exit.
Two Camachos, who stayed on the street, spot her as she  leaves. Racing through the alley, Eddie spots them running in the next block.
Running east on Lake Street, she glances over her shoulde She doesn't see them. She ducks into the alley. But the  Comachos round the corner just in time to catch a glimpse her.
This alley leads to the lower level of Michigan Avenue. S turns back to find the exit blocked by the Comachos. She  flees downward.

The green flourescents of the "Emerald City" give a death cast to the underground street as Diana rounds the corner and collapses against the wall. Her heart pounding like a frightened deer, she has run as far as she can. Pompas Comacho and two of his colleagues come racing arou the corner. They spot her crouched against the wall. She starts to SCREAM but Angel grabs her by the collar an pulls her up to his face and she stops, wide-eyed with te as he touches her throat with his knife.
Come on, Chika. We gonna have some  fun. You gonna take us to your father.
We hear a loud metallic CLICK. We see the barrel of a hug revolver. They wheel to see Eddie crouched, gun drawn, in the alley entrance.
Pompas, you're getting to be a fucking  pain in the ass.
The boys put their hands up, but Eddie doesn't see the th SAMO, coming up behind him. Angel grabs Diana by the hair, shielding himself, and sta backing up the stairs that lead to the street.
Let her go, pooch.

Samo jumps Eddie, and the gun goes flying. It hits the  pavement and bounces off the high curb into the street. In a staggering blur Eddie takes out the Comachos, kickin the last one end over end. But Angel and the girl have  disappeared to the street above. Eddie retrieves his gun and runs up the steps.

With a knife at her side, Angel Comacho leads Diana up th steps of the old el station. They pass through the turnst out onto the platform just as the train pulls to in. Ange forces her onto the train. Eddie comes pounding up the steps and onto the platform j in time to stop the closing train door with his foot.

Eddie wedges his way aboard and the train pulls out. The  passengers looks at him like he's crazy. Eddie works his way through the cars toward the rear. Angel spots him. Knife still in hand, he pulls Diana from car to car past the terrified passengers until finally he cornered at the end of the train. Angel searches frantica for a way out. Eddie enters. Diana sees him.
Another step, and I take her head  off.
You don't have the balls.
Eddie takes another step. Diana slams her elbow into Angel's groin, and breaks free Angel jumps back. He breaks open the rear door and climbs out.

Angel climbs up the back of the car onto the roof. Eddie's right behind him. The spectacular pursuit from car to car on the roof of th speeding el train is witnessed by startled second-floor  secretaries whose desks look directly out at the roof of passing cars.
Angel and Eddie's figures appear as specks, roaring throu the canyon of skyscrapers.

A low bridge forces both men to hug the roof of the train Eddie recovers first and grabs Angel, pulling him down. T roll from side to side on the roof, nearly slipping over side. With a desperate shove, Angel breaks free. Eddie po his gun at him. The train is now over the Chicago River.  Angel dives into the water. Eddie reholsters his gun and dives in after him.
We see Diana's looking out the window of the train. She  follows Eddie's decent with her eyes.

Dozens of startled pedestrians line the bridge railing as Eddie swims toward Angel, bobbing in the middle of the st A hotdogger in a speedboat is racing up the river and Ang is directly in his path. The skipper, showing off for his passengers, doesn't notice him until he hears the sickeni THUNK under the keel. The boat's wake is suddenly red wit blood.

Eddie is helped from the water by a couple of passersby. He stands there, soaking wet, looking around. A crowd is gathering. We hear SIRENS in the background. T he spots her. Diana is standing on the bridge watching him.
Eddie walks to Diana, and she folds into his arms. He hol her a second.
Eddie, now in dry clothes, and Diana walk along the lagoo They talk, argue, and she sits on a bench and cries. Eddi comforts her.
Where are you taking me?
Downtown first. Then I'm gonna place  you in protective custody.
The hell you are!
You'll be safe --
I'll take my chances.
NOTE: Ad lib dialogue throughout scene for possible later use. NOTE: Radio newscast describing the Luna killings can be  mixed with the above dialogue.
Eddie and Diana climb the stairs.
The DOORBELL buzzes repeatedly.
(shouts) Keep your goddamn pants on!
Pirelli, padding across the floor in his shorts, looks li a bear called out of hibernation. He has a service revolv in his hand. He peers through the peep hole, then unbolts the door.
This your idea of a social call?
Eddie enters with Diana.
Fred Pirelli, this is Diana. Diana  Luna.
Pirelli reacts to the name. Diana is in a daze, close to shock. Pirelli takes her and leads her to the couch.
C'mon, kid. Let's get you off your  feet.
Eddie motions him aside.
Can you put her up till I find her  old man?
Does a bear...?
Am I putting you on the spot?
I spent 30 years on the spot. What  ever you need.
Eddie starts to go, and Diana reacts, suddenly frightened
Eddie?
I'll be right across the hall. I'm  just gonna clean up.
He leaves.
Eddie falls fully clothed onto the mattress. The PHONE RI He rolls over in disbelief, staring at the ceiling. It RINGS, and RINGS again and again and again. He finally picks it up.

This is the after-hours watering hole for the police forc and half the cops we've seen so far, including Cragie, ar clustered at the bar or playing darts at the back of the  room. There are a half a dozen women there also. Three of them are cops. Kosalas is here too. He's been drinking. He leans against the wall talking on the pay phone by the men's room.
(to phone) Say, Eddie. Why don' you come by and  tip a few? (pause) Cause I gotta talk to you. (pause) Yeah, I know. But we gotta talk. (pause) Please. (pause) Yeah, at Mike's.
He hangs up and heads back to his table, passing Officer  Music at the bar.
You oughta crash, man. You had a  helluva day.
Two tough looking guys are watching the entrance to the b from a car parked across the street. We can HEAR the NOIS from the BAR.
Love it, Flash. Gonna be a slide.  Easy in, easy out.
Just a quick and dirty?
Yeah, yeah, nothin to it. You know  the drill.
They check their weapons.
Everybody but Kosalas is having a good time. Donato, flan by two girls, foot up on a chair, entertains a small crow

He picks her up on Forty-third, and  he's takin' in. She says, "Say, baby.  Ain't no need for goin' downtown."  An' she pulls back her skirt. So the  dumb shit climbs in the back an'  takes a piece... (starts to chuckle) ...an' leaves the keys in the front  and locks the two of 'em in the squad.  And he hasta kick out the window  see, an' she starts screamin', "Rape!  Rape!" An' they charge him with rape  an' every other fuckin' thing in the  book. Internal Affairs is gonna give  him a kayak and a lantern an' put  him out in the lake.

A group laughs at the story. There is a stillness at the  front door. One of the hoods from outside steps in. He we a leather coat. The heads at the bar turn. He walks the length of the bar and enters the john. He is obviously out of place in this saloon. Nobody has both ha on the bar. The front door opens. The other hood steps in, walks up t the bar, and orders.
Bartender. Gimme a black russian and  a Courvoisier.
The First Hood comes out of the bathroom and walks up to bar. Suddenly he whips a sawed-off shotgun from under his coat.
(bellows) Yo! Get your hands up motherfuckers.  This is a ho --
THIRTY HAMMERS CLICK. Thirty guns are drawn. The room is frozen. Only the JUKEBOX makes a sound. The t hoods, eyes fixed on the array of iron pointed at them, c even swallow. Finally...
(to partner) You stupid motherfucker.
The cops swarm the hoods and in an instant they are on th floor being cuffed and roughly handled. Kosalas is at the end of the bar, frozen, his gun still in his holster.
Eddie gets out of his car and heads for the front door.

The place is in an uproar -- everybody doubled up with  LAUGHTER -- as the two luckless hoods, handcuffed togethe are lying on the filthy tavern floor under a table. They  continue to berate each other. Eddie enters.
My old lady tol' me you was fucked  up in the head. Do I listen? Piece o  cake, you say. Snap, you say. Nothin  to it, you say.
Shut up over there.
Donato spots Eddie and calls to him.
Eddie! Partner! Meet Ruthie. Dental  Hygienist. She's oral.
Ruthie giggles.
And this is... Marlene. She works  for a proctologist.
Marlene swats at him.
Siddown, partner. I got a proposition  for you.
Not now, Donato.
O.K. O.K. But just let me plant two  words in your brain. Alligator  farming.
Eddie shakes his head and walks to the back of the room w Kosalas sits hunched over a drink, the only man in the ro not laughing. He looks up whens Eddie pulls over a chair.
Beer?
Eddie nods, and Kosalas signals the waitress. There is a  long beat at Kosalas fidgets and Eddie waits.
Looks like I'm caught between the  rock and the hard place, Sarge.
Eddie just looks at him.

You know I really wanted to be a  good cop, but... shit. It's hard  enough sometimes just to stay alive.  Comes so easy to you. You got all  the fuckin' answers. Me, I'm still  tryin' to find the questions.
Eddie is still silent. Kosalas takes a swig of his beer, finally blurts is out.
Cragie planted the gun on the kid.  Just wasted him, and then I... I  don't know what to do about the  hearing tomorrow...
Tell the truth.
See. It's all so nothin' for you. If  I talk straight every cop on the  force will shit on me. If I don't...  Cragie gets away with murder.
And the chance to do it again. Next  time he might take away a cop. That  make any difference?
He's my partner.
Your partner's selling you out,  Kosalas. He kills an unarmed kid,  and now he's risking your ass to  save his own.
It was a mistake.
It cost an innocent kid his life.
I know that! I KNOW THAT!
He is too loud, and attracts attention.
(softly) Jesus. I see that kid's face every  time I close my eyes.
Tell 'em like it is, Nick. I'll back  you up.
Eddie gets up and walks away.
The two amateur holdup men are being hustled out to the p wagon as Eddie heads for the door. Someone grabs his arm. It's Cragie, a little drunk.
Nice to see you out with the boys  for a change, Sarge.
Hello, Cragie.
They tell me my Sergeant wouldn't  sign for me. You want to tell me  why?
You know why.
No. Tell me.
(gently) You were a good cop for a lot of  years. You've passed your limit now  Cragie.
Fuck you. Where do you get off?
Right about here.
Eddie walks out the door.
Eddie buzzes the door. Pirelli opens it. He lets Eddie in scans the hall, and closes it.
Pirelli sets down his gun, and pours Eddie a cup of coffe
She's havin' a bad night. Gave her a  shot of brandy. Maybe she'll sleep.
Giving liquor to a minor, Pirelli?
He turns to leave.
I'll be back right after the hearing  tomorrow, and you can get some sleep  then.

Eddie cracks the door and peeks in. Diana sits on the bed lonely forlorn figure. She looks at Eddie, and tries a smile that fails. Eddie walks over to sit on the bed next to her. She falls apart, and lies down, on the verge of crying,  collapsing so that her head rest in Eddie's lap. They are quiet like that for a moment, she curled into a  ball, Eddie stroking her hair.
What do you do when you don't have  anyone?
You find someone.
She looks up at him.
Could you... Hold me for a while?
Eddie lays on the bed beside her. She curls up in his arm and closes her eyes. Eddie's eyes remain open.

The Civilian Review Board is in the Office of Professiona Standards. The panel consists of eight civilians. It is a real cross-section of the city of Chicago. Leon Partida c the proceedings. We recognize several faces from the open bust. An old Mexican woman is on the stand facing the panel. Cr sits at a table with his representative, facing the offic A female panel member is questioning the old woman.
How far were you standing from where  your grandson was shot, Mrs. Murillio?
The question must be TRANSLATED by a bumbling clerk, the woman answers in Spanish, then the answer is translated.
In the next doorway. Four meters.

The room is packed. In addition to the police officers,  character witnesses, and friends of the dead kid, there a a dozen reporters. Eddie enters and looks over the scene. He nods to Donato, sitting at the rail with his foot propped up.
How you doin', Sarge?
What's the score?
(nods toward witness) Kid's grandmother says Cragie threw  down the pistola.
Eddie takes a seat. Officer Cragie is called back to the  witness stand.
(to steno) Officer Cragie has already been sworn. (pause) Officer Cragie, you have heard Mrs.  Murillio's testimony --
Yes, sir.
Cragie is neat as a pin, humble, cooperative to a fault.
You have heard her tell this panel  that she saw you lay the gun in her  grandson's hand.
He feigns compassion.

I'm not saying the woman would make  this up. But there's no way she could  have seen anything from where she  was standing in a hallway that dark. (pause) Like you said, she's the boy's  grandmother.
If it was dark, Officer, how were  you sure Vega had a gun?
We were lucky. There was a glint of  light, a reflection comin off the  barrel of the weapon.
A carload of Comachos, including Luis, cruises down the s and parks in the alley next to Eddie's building.
The hearing is in recess and the hall is filled with smok and coffee drinkers. Eddie is getting a BUSY SIGNAL on the pay phone. Donato approaches.
You think he'll get a pass?
You heard it all. What do you think?
If the hearing was over I'd have to  put my money on the old lady. (smiles) But Kosalas's next. My bet's on  Cragie.
The kid may surprise you.
Eddie dials the number again. Still a busy signal.
Pirelli has Eddie's answering machine plugged in, and is  tinkering with the insides. Diana comes into the living room, toweling her wet hair,  just out of the shower, but in her street clothes.
Kosalas is on the witness stand.
And right after you heard Officer  Cragie's gun discharge, what did you  do then?
I immediately advanced down the hall.
And what did you see?
The deceased, Vega, lying on the  floor. Officer Cragie was checking  his vital signs.
What happened then?
We recovered a .25 calibre automatic  from the teenager's right hand.
Did you see that weapon in Vega's  hand before Officer Cragie fired?
Yes, sir.
Cragie leans back. A ripple is felt in the crowd. The reaction of the boy's  relatives, delayed by translation, is one of outrage.
No more questions.

As Kosalas steps down he keeps his eyes on the floor ahea of him avoiding eye contact. Eddie leans back in his seat. A couple of people get up a head for the door. Eddie gets to his feet and heads for the door. Partida hi the gavel.
I'd like to now call Sergeant Cusack.
Eddie halts with his hand on the knob.
Pirelli works on the answering machine, but the phone is  reconnected. Diana is looking at photographs on the wall.
You made that uniform look good.
Pirelli looks up.
That good looking gorilla next to me  is Eddie's father. Better than good  cop. Killed in the line of duty.  '71. (pause) Another cop shot him. An accident.
He goes back to the machine.

The Comachos come up the stairs, led by Luis. They stop a Eddie's door. They pull out their guns, and kick the door in. Across the hall, Pirelli's door opens, and Pirelli, holdi his pistol steps into the hall. The Comachos turn and fire, blasting Pirelli back into hi apartment. Through the open door we see Diana dash across the living room.
Luis and his men burst in. Diana runs for the phone. A Comacho takes it from her and rips it from the wall. Diana is caught by two Comachos.
Eddie is on the witness stand.
I can't comment on that. It was over  before I got there.
You are his superior officer, are  you not?
Cragie's in my unit, yes.
Did you give the men their various  assignments?
I did.
Did you request that officer Cragie  be on your TAC team?
No, I didn't.
Partida lifts a document from the table.

Sergeant... I have here a department  document dated 24 September, of last  year. It is a request by you, to  your superiors, to have Officer Cragie  transferred to another unit. Are you  familiar with this document?
Yes.
The room listens to every word.
Why did you request his transfer?
Maybe 30 years is too long for anyone  to look at the city's guts, Mr.  Partida.
What happened to this request?
It was denied.
Partida lifts another document.
This is a letter of support for  Officer Cragie. (hands it to him) Everyone in his unit signed it but  you. (pause) Why?
Eddie glances over the letter and hands it back.
I don't agree with what it says.
Are you saying you do not believe  Officer Cragie is fit to work the  streets of Chicago?
That's what I'm saying.

The reporters are clustered around Eddie as he emerges bu he walks past them back to the pay phone. He puts in a qu and dials. Frowns. The cops in the corridor are passing the word about Eddie testimony, discussing it in little clusters. Their appear is frightening. Eddie dials another number.
(to phone) I just dialed 348-6610, and I get  this funny buzz. Check the line for  me? Thanks.
Cragie, backed up by a couple of buddies, comes up to him
Seems to me the man's got his tongue  stuck to his asshole, Cragie.
Hey, that don't bother him. He's the  fuckin White Knight. (to Eddie) You wanna take on the whole world by  yourself? Now you're gonna get your  chance, Sarge.
They walk down the hall.
(from phone) Sorry, sir, that number seems to be  out of service. I've reported it.
Eddie drops the phone.
Eddie races down the hallway past hostile clusters of for friends.
Roaring north on the boulevard without regard to traffic, Eddie speeds toward his house in his rattling Chevy.
Eddie rockets through the red lights LEANING on his HORN.

Eddie runs up the stairs, and slows when he sees Odell. T boy is sitting on the floor, head in his hands, crying. Just past Odell, several uniformed policemen are standing over Pirelli's body. They step back as Eddie approaches.
He was a friend of yours wasn't he?
Yeah.
Eddie hurries to the bedroom and back. He rushes out of t apartment.
Eddie runs for the Chevy and peels away from the curb.
Eddie is on the radio, speeding west on Diversey Parkway.
(to mike) Squad, this is 1462. I need a backup.  Have 64 and 63 from TAC 4 meet me at  the billiard parlor on 18th near  Halsted. Questioning suspects.
Music is standing on a streetcorner talking to a couple o hookers. Down the street, Brennan waits in their unmarked car.
(from speaker) 1463 and 1464, Unit 1462 requesting  assistance at the poolroom on 18th  Street near Halsted. Questioning a  suspect.
Brennan picks up the mike.
(to mike) Ten-four, Dispatch. Unit 1463  responding.
Music returns to the car and gets in.
I could use a cup of coffee.
Eddie squeals to a stop, hops out of the car, starts for pool hall. Eddie enters the poolhall.

The place is busy. Everybody in sight is either mean or u Eddie enters and a dozen pair of eyes are on him. The pool players not connected with this confrontation ta one look at him, hang up their cues, and split. Eddie heads for the back of the room. A pair of heavyweig fall in behind him. One of them grabs Eddie.
Hey, you ain't got no business back  there.
I want your opinion I'll beat it out  of you.

Eddie spins with deadly precision and catches them in mid step and they go down like gut-shot rhinos. He heads for the rear hallway and everybody clears a path He steps up to the door in back and kicks it in.
A startled Camacho, DEGAS, looks up, straw in hand with a line of coke on a mirror on his desk.
Where is Luis?
Get the hell out of here.
Eddie grabs Degas by the hair and starts slamming his fac into the mirror which shatters with every blow.
Talk to me, Degas, or I'll hit you  with so many lefts you're gonna beg  for a right.
He holds up Degas' head to look him in the eye. Blood and cocaine stain the man's face.
He's coming here. He's on his way.
Eddie lifts the head once and gives Degas one punch in th face that sends him ass over teakettle across the floor.
Beneath the lighted map of Area 4, the police dispatcher  trying to raise Eddie's backup.
We need a verification on a back-up  for Unit 1462...
The dispatcher at the next panel overhears the call.
1462. That's Cusack, right?
First dispatcher nods.
Good luck finding a backup for that  character.

Eddie opens the door and emerges from the back room. A do Comacho goons have gathered. Behind them are another two  dozen hostile spectators. But no sign of the backup. He pulls out his gun. The remaining innocent bystanders s for the exit. Eddie walks forward into the room. The Coma and their soldiers stand around him. Several have guns. Eddie keeps them under the point of his gun. He gets to t door and has to turn his back on it to keep the gang in h sights. A gun is pressed into Eddie's back. He drops his gun. Luis kicks Eddie across the room. Eddie lands at the feet the gang.
Take him apart.

Eddie springs to his feet, and in the same motion decks h nearest attacker. The battle is on. Hardwood pool cues cr around him. The first four or five never get a chance to lay a finger him. Battered and broken, they litter the billiard tables and floor. But Eddie is outnumbered 20 to 1.
Cragie and Kosalas sit at the bar. The TV is off, and the few customers pay attention to the police monitor.
(from radio) ...request verification for backup  for unit 1462. Patrol 47, are you in  the area.
(from radio) Squad. 47. We're having vehicular  problems. Not able to respond.
Cragie smiles. Kosalas looks ashamed.
Two uniformed police sit in a cruiser.
(from radio) ...need backup at 18th and Halstead...
One cop turns to the other.
Fuck him.

Coming at Eddie now from all sides, the Comachos wear int him. Finally they begin to connect. Blind-sided, he goes  down and they are on him like jackals. They drag him to the top of the rear stairs, and kick him down to the alley. It seems like they are about to finish him off when sudde all is quiet. The crowd parts. Eddie looks up through swo eyes to see Luis Comacho standing above him, cool as ice. Luis reaches down and pulls Eddie's head up by the ear.
The sun comes up. You give me Luna,  or the girl dies -- slow.
Luis kicks him in the face.

Eddie opens a bloody eye and looks over his surroundings. He's alone. He moves, a joint at a time, checking himself out. Staggering to his feet, he opens a spiggot on the wall. H lets the cold water wash over his head.
Donato hobbles through the deserted pool hall, his pistol his hand.
Donato comes out the back door of the poolhall, and finds Eddie sitting on his haunches and resting against a wall  between two garbage cans.
I would have been here, Sarge. They  kept it from me.
You're Ok, Hopalong.
Donato holsters his gun, and helps Eddie to his feet.
Listen, I'm havin' a drink with this  friend of mine, name of Mickie. She  works on a computer over in the  Federal Building, FBI. I got here as  soon as I heard.
They got Diana Luna.
That's what I'm tryin' to tell ya.  Mickie told me she read on the wire  Tony Luna's comin' into Union Station  at ten tonight.
Eddie runs down the alley toward his car.
Eddie's car pulls up. He gets out and runs inside.
A train sits at the platform. Tony Luna is walking down t platform.
Eddie runs through the cavernous lobby.
Eddie arrives in time to see Tony step into a waiting Cad that immediately takes off. Eddie races up the ramp to his car.
Eddie jumps into his car, and roars away in pursuit of th Cadillac.
Tony settles in, and then sees Scalese sitting calmly in back seat.
(surprised) Hello, Felix.
Hello, Tony.
Tony moves for his gun. The hood next to Tony relieves hi of his gun, using his own for persuasion.
(sighs) You see, Tony. You make no sense.  You start a war... Waste people...  Money... You're like a kid, Tony.  You're a bad boy.
Tony is scared. The driver spots something in the rearvie mirror.
The Cadillac rockets through the empty orange-lighted can of the financial district, with Eddie in hot pursuit.
Roaring north on Wacker past an astonished group in front the Civic Opera House, the Cadillac drops out of sight on the down-ramp to Lower Wacker.
This bi-level street is as different as night and day. Th lower level's eerie green lights make us feel like we're  under water. Iron girders and concrete pillars support th street above.

The Cadillac races through this vast man-made cavern, pas the sub-level loading docks and service entrances of  skyscrapers above. City work crews and all night commerci deliveries dot both the upper and lower levels of the cha
Eddie is gaining in the battered Chevy. The Cadillac rock up the next ramp to the street level.
The Cadillac zooms up from below, crosses the intersectio and immediately takes the next down-ramp. Eddie flies up  from below, briefly airborne, barreling after them into t tunnel.

A block later the Cadillac heads topside again. Eddie tak a gamble and goes straight ahead.
